After a king who had twelve beautiful daughters came several others; but several others had all the same luck, and several others lost several others's lives in the same manner. Now it chanced that an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer, passed through the country where a king who had twelve beautiful daughters reigned: and as an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer was travelling through a wood, an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer met an old woman, who asked an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer where an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer was going. ‘an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer hardly know where an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer am going, or what an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer had better do,’ said an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer; ‘but an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer think an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer should like very well to find out where it is that twelve beautiful daughters dance, and then in time an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer might be a king.’ ‘Well,’ said an old woman, who asked him where he was going, ‘find is no very hard task: only take care not to drink any of the wine which one of twelve beautiful daughters will bring to an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer in the evening; and as soon as one of the princesses leaves an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer pretend to be fast asleep.’ Then an old woman, who asked him where he was going gave an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer a cloak, and said, ‘As soon as an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer put a cloak on an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer will become invisible, and an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer will then be able to follow twelve beautiful daughters wherever twelve beautiful daughters go.’ When an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer heard all this good counsel, an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer determined to try an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer's luck: so an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer went to a king who had twelve beautiful daughters, and said an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer was willing to undertake the task. an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer was as well received as twelve beautiful daughters had been, and a king who had twelve beautiful daughters ordered fine royal robes to be given an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer; and when the evening came an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer was led to the outer chamber. Just as an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer was going to lie down, the eldest of twelve beautiful daughters brought an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer a cup of wine; but an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer threw a cup of wine away secretly, taking care not to drink a drop. Then an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer laid an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer down on an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer's bed, and in a little while began to snore very loud as if an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer was fast asleep. When twelve beautiful daughters heard began twelve beautiful daughters laughed heartily; and the eldest of the princesses said, ‘This fellow too might have done a wiser thing than lose an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer's life in this way!’ Then twelve beautiful daughters rose up and opened twelve beautiful daughters's drawers and boxes, and took out all twelve beautiful daughters's fine clothes, and dressed twelve beautiful daughters at the glass, and skipped about as if twelve beautiful daughters were eager to begin dancing. But the youngest said, ‘the youngest don’t know how it is, while twelve beautiful daughters are so happy the youngest feel very uneasy; the youngest am sure some mischance will befall us.’ ‘the youngest,’ said the eldest of the princesses, ‘the youngest are always afraid; have the youngest forgotten how many kings’ sons have already watched in vain? And as for an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer, even if the eldest of the princesses had not given an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer's sleeping draught, an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer would have slept soundly enough.’ When twelve beautiful daughters were all ready, twelve beautiful daughters went and looked at an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer; but an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer snored on, and did not stir hand or foot: so twelve beautiful daughters thought twelve beautiful daughters were quite safe; and the eldest of the princesses went up to the eldest of the princesses's own bed and clapped the eldest of the princesses's hands, and her own bed sank into the floor and a trap-door flew open. an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer saw twelve beautiful daughters going down through a trap-door one after another, the eldest of the princesses leading the way; and thinking an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer had no time to lose, an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer jumped up, put on the cloak which an old woman, who asked him where he was going had given an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer, and followed twelve beautiful daughters; but in the middle of the stairs an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer trod on the gown of the youngest, and the youngest cried out to the youngest's , ‘All is not right; someone took hold of the gown of the youngest princess.’ ‘You silly creature!’ said the eldest of the princesses, ‘the gown of the youngest princess is nothing but a nail in the wall.’ Then down twelve beautiful daughters went, and at the bottom twelve beautiful daughters found twelve beautiful daughters in a most delightful grove of trees; and the leaves were all of silver, and glittered and sparkled beautifully. an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer wished to take away some token of the place; so an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer broke off a little branch, and there came a loud noise from a little branch. Then the youngest said again, ‘the youngest am sure all is not right--did not you hear a loud noise? a loud noise never happened before.’ But the eldest of the princesses said, ‘It is only our princes, who are shouting for joy at our's approach.’ Then our came to another grove of trees, where all the leaves were of gold; and afterwards to a third, where the leaves were all glittering diamonds. And an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer broke a branch from each; and every time there was a loud noise, which made the youngest tremble with fear; but the eldest of the princesses still said, it was only the princes, who were crying for joy. So our went on till our came to a great lake; and at the side of a great lake there lay twelve little boats with twelve handsome princes in twelve little boats with twelve handsome princes in them, who seemed to be waiting there for the princesses, who seemed to be waiting there for twelve beautiful daughters. One of twelve beautiful daughters went into each boat, and an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer stepped into the same boat with the youngest. As our were rowing over a great lake, the prince who was in the same boat with the youngest said, ‘the prince who was in the boat with the youngest princess and the soldier do not know why it is, but though the prince who was in the boat with the youngest princess and the soldier am rowing with all the prince who was in the boat with the youngest princess and the soldier's might our do not get on so fast as usual, and the prince who was in the boat with the youngest princess and the soldier am quite tired: the boat with the youngest princess seems very heavy today.’ ‘It is only the heat of the weather,’ said the youngest: ‘the youngest feel it very warm too.’ On the other side of a great lake stood a fine illuminated castle, from which came the merry music of horns and trumpets. There our landed, and went into a fine illuminated castle, from which came the merry music of horns and trumpets, and each prince danced with each prince's princess; and an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer, danced with twelve beautiful daughters too; and when any of twelve beautiful daughters had a cup of wine set by any of the princesses, any of the princesses drank a cup of wine set by her up, so that when any of the princesses put a cup of wine set by her to any of the princesses's mouth a cup of wine set by her was empty. At this, too, the youngest was terribly frightened, but the eldest of the princesses always silenced the youngest. twelve beautiful daughters danced on till three o’clock in the morning, and then all twelve beautiful daughters's shoes were worn out, so that twelve beautiful daughters were obliged to leave off. twelve handsome princes in them, who seemed to be waiting there for the princesses rowed twelve beautiful daughters back again over a great lake (but this time an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer placed an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer in the boat with the youngest princess with the youngest); and on the opposite shore twelve beautiful daughters took leave of each other, twelve beautiful daughters promising to come again the next night. When twelve beautiful daughters came to the stairs, an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer ran on before twelve beautiful daughters, and laid an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer down; and as twelve beautiful daughters slowly came up very much tired, twelve beautiful daughters heard an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer snoring in an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer's bed; so twelve beautiful daughters said, ‘Now all is quite safe’; then twelve beautiful daughters undressed twelve beautiful daughters, put away twelve beautiful daughters's fine clothes, pulled off twelve beautiful daughters's shoes, and went to bed. In the morning an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer said nothing about what had happened, but determined to see more of this strange adventure, and went again the second and third night; and every thing happened just as before; twelve beautiful daughters danced each time till their shoes were worn to pieces, and then returned home. However, on the third night an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer carried away one of the golden cups as a token of where an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer had been. As soon as the time came when an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer was to declare the secret, an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer was taken before a king who had twelve beautiful daughters with the three branches and one of the golden cups; and twelve beautiful daughters stood listening behind the door to hear what an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer would say. And when a king who had twelve beautiful daughters asked an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer. ‘Where do a king who had twelve beautiful daughters's dance at night?’ an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer answered, ‘With twelve princes in a castle under ground.’ And then an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer told a king who had twelve beautiful daughters all that had happened, and showed a king who had twelve beautiful daughters the three branches and the golden cup. Then a king who had twelve beautiful daughters called for twelve beautiful daughters, and asked twelve beautiful daughters whether what an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer said was true: and when twelve beautiful daughters saw that twelve beautiful daughters were discovered, and that it was of no use to deny what had happened, twelve beautiful daughters confessed it all. And a king who had twelve beautiful daughters asked an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer which of twelve beautiful daughters a king who had twelve beautiful daughters would choose for a king who had twelve beautiful daughters's wife; and an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer answered, ‘a king who had twelve beautiful daughters am not very young, so a king who had twelve beautiful daughters will have the youngest.’--And they were married that very day, and an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer was chosen to be a king who had twelve beautiful daughters heir.

Title: THE FISHERMAN AND HIS WIFE
Text: There was once a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside. The fisherman used to go out all day long a-fishing; and one day, as he sat on the shore with his rod, looking at the sparkling waves and watching his line, all on a sudden his float was dragged away deep into the water: and in drawing it up he pulled out a great fish. But the fish said, ‘Pray let me live! I am not a real fish; I am an enchanted prince: put me in the water again, and let me go!’ ‘Oh, ho!’ said the man, ‘you need not make so many words about the matter; I will have nothing to do with a fish that can talk: so swim away, sir, as soon as you please!’ Then he put him back into the water, and the fish darted straight down to the bottom, and left a long streak of blood behind him on the wave. When the fisherman went home to his wife in the pigsty, he told her how he had caught a great fish, and how it had told him it was an enchanted prince, and how, on hearing it speak, he had let it go again. ‘Did not you ask it for anything?’ said the wife, ‘we live very wretchedly here, in this nasty dirty pigsty; do go back and tell the fish we want a snug little cottage.’ The fisherman did not much like the business: however, he went to the seashore; and when he came back there the water looked all yellow and green. And he stood at the water’s edge, and said:  ‘O man of the sea!   Hearken to me!   My wife Ilsabill   Will have her own will,   And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’ Then the fish came swimming to him, and said, ‘Well, what is her will? What does your wife want?’ ‘Ah!’ said the fisherman, ‘she says that when I had caught you, I ought to have asked you for something before I let you go; she does not like living any longer in the pigsty, and wants a snug little cottage.’ ‘Go home, then,’ said the fish; ‘she is in the cottage already!’ So the man went home, and saw his wife standing at the door of a nice trim little cottage. ‘Come in, come in!’ said she; ‘is not this much better than the filthy pigsty we had?’ And there was a parlour, and a bedchamber, and a kitchen; and behind the cottage there was a little garden, planted with all sorts of flowers and fruits; and there was a courtyard behind, full of ducks and chickens. ‘Ah!’ said the fisherman, ‘how happily we shall live now!’ ‘We will try to do so, at least,’ said his wife. Everything went right for a week or two, and then Dame Ilsabill said, ‘Husband, there is not near room enough for us in this cottage; the courtyard and the garden are a great deal too small; I should like to have a large stone castle to live in: go to the fish again and tell him to give us a castle.’ ‘Wife,’ said the fisherman, ‘I don’t like to go to him again, for perhaps he will be angry; we ought to be easy with this pretty cottage to live in.’ ‘Nonsense!’ said the wife; ‘he will do it very willingly, I know; go along and try!’ The fisherman went, but his heart was very heavy: and when he came to the sea, it looked blue and gloomy, though it was very calm; and he went close to the edge of the waves, and said:  ‘O man of the sea!   Hearken to me!   My wife Ilsabill   Will have her own will,   And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’ ‘Well, what does she want now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said the man, dolefully, ‘my wife wants to live in a stone castle.’ ‘Go home, then,’ said the fish; ‘she is standing at the gate of it already.’ So away went the fisherman, and found his wife standing before the gate of a great castle. ‘See,’ said she, ‘is not this grand?’ With that they went into the castle together, and found a great many servants there, and the rooms all richly furnished, and full of golden chairs and tables; and behind the castle was a garden, and around it was a park half a mile long, full of sheep, and goats, and hares, and deer; and in the courtyard were stables and cow-houses. ‘Well,’ said the man, ‘now we will live cheerful and happy in this beautiful castle for the rest of our lives.’ ‘Perhaps we may,’ said the wife; ‘but let us sleep upon it, before we make up our minds to that.’ So they went to bed. The next morning when Dame Ilsabill awoke it was broad daylight, and she jogged the fisherman with her elbow, and said, ‘Get up, husband, and bestir yourself, for we must be king of all the land.’ ‘Wife, wife,’ said the man, ‘why should we wish to be the king? I will not be king.’ ‘Then I will,’ said she. ‘But, wife,’ said the fisherman, ‘how can you be king--the fish cannot make you a king?’ ‘Husband,’ said she, ‘say no more about it, but go and try! I will be king.’ So the man went away quite sorrowful to think that his wife should want to be king. This time the sea looked a dark grey colour, and was overspread with curling waves and the ridges of foam as he cried out:  ‘O man of the sea!   Hearken to me!   My wife Ilsabill   Will have her own will,   And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’ ‘Well, what would she have now?’ said the fish. ‘Alas!’ said the poor man, ‘my wife wants to be king.’ ‘Go home,’ said the fish; ‘she is king already.’ Then the fisherman went home; and as he came close to the palace he saw a troop of soldiers, and heard the sound of drums and trumpets. And when he went in he saw his wife sitting on a throne of gold and diamonds, with a golden crown upon her head; and on each side of her stood six fair maidens, each a head taller than the other. ‘Well, wife,’ said the fisherman, ‘are you king?’ ‘Yes,’ said she, ‘I am king.’ And when he had looked at her for a long time, he said, ‘Ah, wife! what a fine thing it is to be king! Now we shall never have anything more to wish for as long as we live.’ ‘I don’t know how that may be,’ said she; ‘never is a long time. I am king, it is true; but I begin to be tired of that, and I think I should like to be emperor.’ ‘Alas, wife! why should you wish to be emperor?’ said the fisherman. ‘Husband,’ said she, ‘go to the fish! I say I will be emperor.’ ‘Ah, wife!’ replied the fisherman, ‘the fish cannot make an emperor, I am sure, and I should not like to ask him for such a thing.’ ‘I am king,’ said Ilsabill, ‘and you are my slave; so go at once!’ So the fisherman was forced to go; and he muttered as he went along, ‘This will come to no good, it is too much to ask; the fish will be tired at last, and then we shall be sorry for what we have done.’ He soon came to the seashore; and the water was quite black and muddy, and a mighty whirlwind blew over the waves and rolled them about, but he went as near as he could to the water’s brink, and said:  ‘O man of the sea!   Hearken to me!   My wife Ilsabill   Will have her own will,   And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’ ‘What would she have now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said the fisherman, ‘she wants to be emperor.’ ‘Go home,’ said the fish; ‘she is emperor already.’ So he went home again; and as he came near he saw his wife Ilsabill sitting on a very lofty throne made of solid gold, with a great crown on her head full two yards high; and on each side of her stood her guards and attendants in a row, each one smaller than the other, from the tallest giant down to a little dwarf no bigger than my finger. And before her stood princes, and dukes, and earls: and the fisherman went up to her and said, ‘Wife, are you emperor?’ ‘Yes,’ said she, ‘I am emperor.’ ‘Ah!’ said the man, as he gazed upon her, ‘what a fine thing it is to be emperor!’ ‘Husband,’ said she, ‘why should we stop at being emperor? I will be pope next.’ ‘O wife, wife!’ said he, ‘how can you be pope? there is but one pope at a time in Christendom.’ ‘Husband,’ said she, ‘I will be pope this very day.’ ‘But,’ replied the husband, ‘the fish cannot make you pope.’ ‘What nonsense!’ said she; ‘if he can make an emperor, he can make a pope: go and try him.’ So the fisherman went. But when he came to the shore the wind was raging and the sea was tossed up and down in boiling waves, and the ships were in trouble, and rolled fearfully upon the tops of the billows. In the middle of the heavens there was a little piece of blue sky, but towards the south all was red, as if a dreadful storm was rising. At this sight the fisherman was dreadfully frightened, and he trembled so that his knees knocked together: but still he went down near to the shore, and said:  ‘O man of the sea!   Hearken to me!   My wife Ilsabill   Will have her own will,   And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’ ‘What does she want now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said the fisherman, ‘my wife wants to be pope.’ ‘Go home,’ said the fish; ‘she is pope already.’ Then the fisherman went home, and found Ilsabill sitting on a throne that was two miles high. And she had three great crowns on her head, and around her stood all the pomp and power of the Church. And on each side of her were two rows of burning lights, of all sizes, the greatest as large as the highest and biggest tower in the world, and the least no larger than a small rushlight. ‘Wife,’ said the fisherman, as he looked at all this greatness, ‘are you pope?’ ‘Yes,’ said she, ‘I am pope.’ ‘Well, wife,’ replied he, ‘it is a grand thing to be pope; and now you must be easy, for you can be nothing greater.’ ‘I will think about that,’ said the wife. Then they went to bed: but Dame Ilsabill could not sleep all night for thinking what she should be next. At last, as she was dropping asleep, morning broke, and the sun rose. ‘Ha!’ thought she, as she woke up and looked at it through the window, ‘after all I cannot prevent the sun rising.’ At this thought she was very angry, and wakened her husband, and said, ‘Husband, go to the fish and tell him I must be lord of the sun and moon.’ The fisherman was half asleep, but the thought frightened him so much that he started and fell out of bed. ‘Alas, wife!’ said he, ‘cannot you be easy with being pope?’ ‘No,’ said she, ‘I am very uneasy as long as the sun and moon rise without my leave. Go to the fish at once!’ Then the man went shivering with fear; and as he was going down to the shore a dreadful storm arose, so that the trees and the very rocks shook. And all the heavens became black with stormy clouds, and the lightnings played, and the thunders rolled; and you might have seen in the sea great black waves, swelling up like mountains with crowns of white foam upon their heads. And the fisherman crept towards the sea, and cried out, as well as he could:  ‘O man of the sea!   Hearken to me!   My wife Ilsabill   Will have her own will,   And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’ ‘What does she want now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said he, ‘she wants to be lord of the sun and moon.’ ‘Go home,’ said the fish, ‘to your pigsty again.’ And there they live to this very day.

The next morning when his wife awoke it was broad daylight, and his wife jogged a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside with his wife's elbow, and said, ‘Get up, a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, and bestir a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, for we must be king of all the land.’ ‘his wife, wife,’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, ‘why should we wish to be the king? a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside will not be king.’ ‘Then his wife will,’ said his wife. ‘But, his wife,’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, ‘how can his wife be king--a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside cannot make his wife a king?’ ‘a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside,’ said his wife, ‘say no more about it, but go and try! his wife will be king.’ So a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside went away quite sorrowful to think that his wife should want to be king. This time the sea looked a dark grey colour, and was overspread with curling waves and the ridges of foam as a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside cried out:  ‘O man of the seathe sea!   Hearken to a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside! his wife his wife   Will have his wife's own will,   And hath sent a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside to beg a boon of O man of the sea!’ ‘Well, what would his wife have now?’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside. ‘Alas!’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, ‘his wife wants to be king.’ ‘Go home,’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside; ‘his wife is king already.’ Then a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside went home; and as a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside came close to the palace a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside saw a troop of soldiers, and heard the sound of drums and trumpets. And when a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside went in a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside saw his wife sitting on a throne of gold and diamonds, with a golden crown upon his wife's head; and on each side of his wife stood six fair maidens, each a head taller than the other. ‘Well, his wife,’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, ‘are his wife king?’ ‘Yes,’ said his wife, ‘his wife am king.’ And when a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside had looked at his wife for a long time, a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside said, ‘Ah, his wife! what a fine thing it is to be king! Now we shall never have anything more to wish for as long as we live.’ ‘his wife don’t know how that may be,’ said his wife; ‘never is a long time. his wife am king, it is true; but his wife begin to be tired of king, and his wife think his wife should like to be emperor.’ ‘Alas, his wife! why should his wife wish to be emperor?’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside. ‘a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside,’ said his wife, ‘go to a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside! his wife say his wife will be emperor.’ ‘Ah, his wife!’ replied a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, ‘a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside cannot make an emperor, a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside am sure, and a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside should not like to ask a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside for such a thing.’ ‘his wife am king,’ said his wife, ‘and a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside are his wife's slave; so go at once!’ So a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside was forced to go; and a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside muttered as a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside went along, ‘This will come to no good, This is too much to ask; a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside will be tired at last, and then we shall be sorry for what we have done.’ a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside soon came to the seaside; and the water was quite black and muddy, and a mighty whirlwind blew over the waves and rolled the waves about, but a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside went as near as a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside could to the water's brink, and said:  ‘O man of the seathe sea!   Hearken to a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside! his wife his wife   Will have his wife's own will,   And hath sent a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside to beg a boon of O man of the sea!’ ‘What would his wife have now?’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside. ‘Ah!’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, ‘his wife wants to be emperor.’ ‘Go home,’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside; ‘his wife is emperor already.’ So a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside went home again; and as a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside came near a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside saw his wife sitting on a very lofty throne made of solid gold, with a great crown on his wife's head full two yards high; and on each side of his wife stood his wife's guards and attendants in a row, each one smaller than the other, from the tallest giant down to a little dwarf no bigger than his wife's finger. And before his wife's stood princes, and dukes, and earls: and a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside went up to his wife and said, ‘his wife, are his wife emperor?’ ‘Yes,’ said his wife, ‘his wife am emperor.’ ‘Ah!’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, as a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside gazed upon his wife, ‘what a fine thing it is to be emperor!’ ‘a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside,’ said his wife, ‘why should we stop at being emperor? his wife will be pope next.’ ‘his wife, his wife!’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, ‘how can his wife be pope? there is but one pope at a time in Christendom.’ ‘a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside,’ said his wife, ‘his wife will be pope this very day.’ ‘But,’ replied a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, ‘a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside cannot make his wife pope.’ ‘What nonsense!’ said his wife; ‘if a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside can make an emperor, a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside can make a pope: go and try a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside.’ So a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside went. But when a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside came to the shore the wind was raging and the sea was tossed up and down in boiling waves, and the ships were in trouble, and rolled fearfully upon the tops of the billows. In the middle of the heavens there was a little piece of blue sky, but towards the south all was red, as if a dreadful storm was rising. At this sight a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside was dreadfully frightened, and a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside trembled so that a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside's knees knocked together: but still a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside went down near to the shore, and said:  ‘O man of the seathe sea!   Hearken to a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside! his wife his wife   Will have his wife's own will,   And hath sent a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside to beg a boon of O man of the sea!’ ‘What does his wife want now?’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside. ‘Ah!’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, ‘his wife wants to be pope.’ ‘Go home,’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside; ‘his wife is pope already.’ Then a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside went home, and found his wife sitting on a very lofty throne made of solid gold. And his wife had three great crowns on his wife's head, and around his wife stood all the pomp and power of the Church. And on each side of his wife were two rows of burning lights, of all sizes, the greatest as large as the highest and biggest tower in the world, and the least no larger than a small rushlight. ‘his wife,’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, as a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside looked at all this greatness, ‘are his wife pope?’ ‘Yes,’ said his wife, ‘his wife am pope.’ ‘Well, his wife,’ replied a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, ‘it is a grand thing to be pope; and now his wife must be easy, for his wife can be nothing greater.’ ‘his wife will think about that,’ said his wife. Then we went to bed: but his wife could not sleep all night for thinking what his wife should be next. At last, as his wife was dropping asleep, morning broke, and the sun rose. ‘Ha!’ thought his wife, as his wife woke up and looked at the sun through the window, ‘after all his wife cannot prevent the sun rising.’ At this thought his wife was very angry, and wakened his wife's , and said, ‘a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, go to a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside and tell a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside his wife must be lord of the sun and moon.’ a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside was half asleep, but the thought frightened a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside so much that a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside started and fell out of bed. ‘Alas, his wife!’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, ‘cannot his wife be easy with being pope?’ ‘No,’ said his wife, ‘his wife am very uneasy as long as the sun and moon rise without his wife's leave. Go to a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside at once!’ Then a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside went shivering with fear; and as a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside was going down to the shore a dreadful storm arose, so that the trees and the very rocks shook. And all the heavens became black with stormy clouds, and the lightnings played, and the thunders rolled; and you might have seen in the sea great black waves, swelling up like mountains with crowns of white foam upon her head. And a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside crept towards the sea, and cried out, as well as a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside could:  ‘O man of the seathe sea!   Hearken to a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside! his wife his wife   Will have his wife's own will,   And hath sent a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside to beg a boon of O man of the sea!’ ‘What does his wife want now?’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside. ‘Ah!’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, ‘his wife wants to be lord of the sun and moon.’ ‘Go home,’ said a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside, ‘to a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside's pigsty again.’ And there we live to this very day.

Title: THE WILLOW-WREN AND THE BEAR
Text: Once in summer-time the bear and the wolf were walking in the forest, and the bear heard a bird singing so beautifully that he said: ‘Brother wolf, what bird is it that sings so well?’ ‘That is the King of birds,’ said the wolf, ‘before whom we must bow down.’ In reality the bird was the willow-wren. ‘IF that’s the case,’ said the bear, ‘I should very much like to see his royal palace; come, take me thither.’ ‘That is not done quite as you seem to think,’ said the wolf; ‘you must wait until the Queen comes,’ Soon afterwards, the Queen arrived with some food in her beak, and the lord King came too, and they began to feed their young ones. The bear would have liked to go at once, but the wolf held him back by the sleeve, and said: ‘No, you must wait until the lord and lady Queen have gone away again.’ So they took stock of the hole where the nest lay, and trotted away. The bear, however, could not rest until he had seen the royal palace, and when a short time had passed, went to it again. The King and Queen had just flown out, so he peeped in and saw five or six young ones lying there. ‘Is that the royal palace?’ cried the bear; ‘it is a wretched palace, and you are not King’s children, you are disreputable children!’ When the young wrens heard that, they were frightfully angry, and screamed: ‘No, that we are not! Our parents are honest people! Bear, you will have to pay for that!’ The bear and the wolf grew uneasy, and turned back and went into their holes. The young willow-wrens, however, continued to cry and scream, and when their parents again brought food they said: ‘We will not so much as touch one fly’s leg, no, not if we were dying of hunger, until you have settled whether we are respectable children or not; the bear has been here and has insulted us!’ Then the old King said: ‘Be easy, he shall be punished,’ and he at once flew with the Queen to the bear’s cave, and called in: ‘Old Growler, why have you insulted my children? You shall suffer for it--we will punish you by a bloody war.’ Thus war was announced to the Bear, and all four-footed animals were summoned to take part in it, oxen, asses, cows, deer, and every other animal the earth contained. And the willow-wren summoned everything which flew in the air, not only birds, large and small, but midges, and hornets, bees and flies had to come. When the time came for the war to begin, the willow-wren sent out spies to discover who was the enemy’s commander-in-chief. The gnat, who was the most crafty, flew into the forest where the enemy was assembled, and hid herself beneath a leaf of the tree where the password was to be announced. There stood the bear, and he called the fox before him and said: ‘Fox, you are the most cunning of all animals, you shall be general and lead us.’ ‘Good,’ said the fox, ‘but what signal shall we agree upon?’ No one knew that, so the fox said: ‘I have a fine long bushy tail, which almost looks like a plume of red feathers. When I lift my tail up quite high, all is going well, and you must charge; but if I let it hang down, run away as fast as you can.’ When the gnat had heard that, she flew away again, and revealed everything, down to the minutest detail, to the willow-wren. When day broke, and the battle was to begin, all the four-footed animals came running up with such a noise that the earth trembled. The willow-wren with his army also came flying through the air with such a humming, and whirring, and swarming that every one was uneasy and afraid, and on both sides they advanced against each other. But the willow-wren sent down the hornet, with orders to settle beneath the fox’s tail, and sting with all his might. When the fox felt the first string, he started so that he lifted one leg, from pain, but he bore it, and still kept his tail high in the air; at the second sting, he was forced to put it down for a moment; at the third, he could hold out no longer, screamed, and put his tail between his legs. When the animals saw that, they thought all was lost, and began to flee, each into his hole, and the birds had won the battle. Then the King and Queen flew home to their children and cried: ‘Children, rejoice, eat and drink to your heart’s content, we have won the battle!’ But the young wrens said: ‘We will not eat yet, the bear must come to the nest, and beg for pardon and say that we are honourable children, before we will do that.’ Then the willow-wren flew to the bear’s hole and cried: ‘Growler, you are to come to the nest to my children, and beg their pardon, or else every rib of your body shall be broken.’ So the bear crept thither in the greatest fear, and begged their pardon. And now at last the young wrens were satisfied, and sat down together and ate and drank, and made merry till quite late into the night.

Title: THE FROG-PRINCE
Text: One fine evening a young princess put on her bonnet and clogs, and went out to take a walk by herself in a wood; and when she came to a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it, she sat herself down to rest a while. Now she had a golden ball in her hand, which was her favourite plaything; and she was always tossing it up into the air, and catching it again as it fell. After a time she threw it up so high that she missed catching it as it fell; and the ball bounded away, and rolled along upon the ground, till at last it fell down into the spring. The princess looked into the spring after her ball, but it was very deep, so deep that she could not see the bottom of it. Then she began to bewail her loss, and said, ‘Alas! if I could only get my ball again, I would give all my fine clothes and jewels, and everything that I have in the world.’ Whilst she was speaking, a frog put its head out of the water, and said, ‘Princess, why do you weep so bitterly?’ ‘Alas!’ said she, ‘what can you do for me, you nasty frog? My golden ball has fallen into the spring.’ The frog said, ‘I want not your pearls, and jewels, and fine clothes; but if you will love me, and let me live with you and eat from off your golden plate, and sleep upon your bed, I will bring you your ball again.’ ‘What nonsense,’ thought the princess, ‘this silly frog is talking! He can never even get out of the spring to visit me, though he may be able to get my ball for me, and therefore I will tell him he shall have what he asks.’ So she said to the frog, ‘Well, if you will bring me my ball, I will do all you ask.’ Then the frog put his head down, and dived deep under the water; and after a little while he came up again, with the ball in his mouth, and threw it on the edge of the spring. As soon as the young princess saw her ball, she ran to pick it up; and she was so overjoyed to have it in her hand again, that she never thought of the frog, but ran home with it as fast as she could. The frog called after her, ‘Stay, princess, and take me with you as you said,’ But she did not stop to hear a word. The next day, just as the princess had sat down to dinner, she heard a strange noise--tap, tap--plash, plash--as if something was coming up the marble staircase: and soon afterwards there was a gentle knock at the door, and a little voice cried out and said:  ‘Open the door, my princess dear,   Open the door to thy true love here!   And mind the words that thou and I said   By the fountain cool, in the greenwood shade.’ Then the princess ran to the door and opened it, and there she saw the frog, whom she had quite forgotten. At this sight she was sadly frightened, and shutting the door as fast as she could came back to her seat. The king, her father, seeing that something had frightened her, asked her what was the matter. ‘There is a nasty frog,’ said she, ‘at the door, that lifted my ball for me out of the spring this morning: I told him that he should live with me here, thinking that he could never get out of the spring; but there he is at the door, and he wants to come in.’ While she was speaking the frog knocked again at the door, and said:  ‘Open the door, my princess dear,   Open the door to thy true love here!   And mind the words that thou and I said   By the fountain cool, in the greenwood shade.’ Then the king said to the young princess, ‘As you have given your word you must keep it; so go and let him in.’ She did so, and the frog hopped into the room, and then straight on--tap, tap--plash, plash--from the bottom of the room to the top, till he came up close to the table where the princess sat. ‘Pray lift me upon chair,’ said he to the princess, ‘and let me sit next to you.’ As soon as she had done this, the frog said, ‘Put your plate nearer to me, that I may eat out of it.’ This she did, and when he had eaten as much as he could, he said, ‘Now I am tired; carry me upstairs, and put me into your bed.’ And the princess, though very unwilling, took him up in her hand, and put him upon the pillow of her own bed, where he slept all night long. As soon as it was light he jumped up, hopped downstairs, and went out of the house. ‘Now, then,’ thought the princess, ‘at last he is gone, and I shall be troubled with him no more.’ But she was mistaken; for when night came again she heard the same tapping at the door; and the frog came once more, and said:  ‘Open the door, my princess dear,   Open the door to thy true love here!   And mind the words that thou and I said   By the fountain cool, in the greenwood shade.’ And when the princess opened the door the frog came in, and slept upon her pillow as before, till the morning broke. And the third night he did the same. But when the princess awoke on the following morning she was astonished to see, instead of the frog, a handsome prince, gazing on her with the most beautiful eyes she had ever seen, and standing at the head of her bed. He told her that he had been enchanted by a spiteful fairy, who had changed him into a frog; and that he had been fated so to abide till some princess should take him out of the spring, and let him eat from her plate, and sleep upon her bed for three nights. ‘You,’ said the prince, ‘have broken his cruel charm, and now I have nothing to wish for but that you should go with me into my father’s kingdom, where I will marry you, and love you as long as you live.’ The young princess, you may be sure, was not long in saying ‘Yes’ to all this; and as they spoke a gay coach drove up, with eight beautiful horses, decked with plumes of feathers and a golden harness; and behind the coach rode the prince’s servant, faithful Heinrich, who had bewailed the misfortunes of his dear master during his enchantment so long and so bitterly, that his heart had well-nigh burst. They then took leave of the king, and got into the coach with eight horses, and all set out, full of joy and merriment, for the prince’s kingdom, which they reached safely; and there they lived happily a great many years.
coreference: One fine evening a young princess put on a young princess's bonnet and clogs, and went out to take a walk by a young princess in a wood; and when a young princess came to a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of a wood, a young princess sat a young princess down to rest a while. Now a young princess had a golden ball in a young princess's hand, which was a young princess's favourite plaything; and a young princess was always tossing a golden ball up into the air, and catching a golden ball again as a golden ball fell. After a time a young princess threw a golden ball up so high that a young princess missed catching a golden ball as a golden ball fell; and a golden ball bounded away, and rolled along upon the ground, till at last a golden ball fell down into a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it. a young princess looked into a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it after a golden ball, but a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it was very deep, so deep that a young princess could not see the bottom of a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it. Then a young princess began to bewail a young princess's loss, and said, ‘Alas! if a young princess could only get a golden ball again, a young princess would give all a young princess's fine clothes and jewels, and everything that a young princess have in the world.’ Whilst a young princess was speaking, a frog put a frog's head out of the water, and said, ‘a young princess, why do a young princess weep so bitterly?’ ‘Alas!’ said a young princess, ‘what can a frog do for a young princess, a frog? a golden ball has fallen into a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it.’ a frog said, ‘a frog want not a young princess's pearls, and jewels, and fine clothes; but if a young princess will love a frog, and let a frog live with a young princess and eat from off a young princess's golden plate, and sleep upon a young princess's bed, a frog will bring a young princess a golden ball again.’ ‘What nonsense,’ thought a young princess, ‘a frog is talking! a frog can never even get out of a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it to visit a young princess, though a frog may be able to get a golden ball for a young princess, and therefore a young princess will tell a frog a frog shall have what a frog asks.’ So a young princess said to a frog, ‘Well, if a frog will bring a young princess a golden ball, a young princess will do all a frog ask.’ Then a frog put its head down, and dived deep under the water; and after a little while a frog came up again, with a golden ball in a frog's mouth, and threw a golden ball on the edge of a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it. As soon as a young princess saw a golden ball, a young princess ran to pick a golden ball up; and a young princess was so overjoyed to have a golden ball in her hand again, that a young princess never thought of a frog, but ran home with a golden ball as fast as a young princess could. a frog called after a young princess, ‘Stay, a young princess, and take a young princess with a frog as a frog said,’ But a young princess did not stop to hear a word. The next day, just as a young princess had sat down to dinner, a young princess heard a strange noise--tap, tap--plash, plash--as if something was coming up the marble staircase: and soon afterwards there was a gentle knock at the door, and a little voice cried out and said:  ‘Open the door, a frog's ,   Open the door to a young princess's true love here!   And mind the words that thou and I said   By the fountain cool, in the greenwood shade.’ Then a young princess ran to the door and opened the door, and there a young princess saw a frog. At this sight a young princess was sadly frightened, and shutting the door as fast as a young princess could came back to a young princess's seat. a frog, seeing that something had frightened a young princess, asked a young princess what was the matter. ‘There is a frog,’ said a young princess, ‘at the door, that lifted a young princess's ball for a young princess out of a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it this morning: a young princess told a frog that a frog should live with a young princess here, thinking that a frog could never get out of a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it; but there a frog is at the door, and a frog wants to come in.’ While a young princess was speaking a frog knocked again at the door, and said:  ‘Open the door, a frog's ,   Open the door to thy true love here!   And mind the words that thou and I said   By the fountain cool, in the greenwood shadethou and I I the fountain coolthe greenwood shade.’ Then a frog said to a young princess, ‘As a young princess have given a young princess's word a young princess must keep your word; so go and let a frog in.’ a young princess did so, and a frog hopped into the room, and then straight on--tap, tap--plash, plash--from the bottom of the room to the top, till a frog came up close to the table where a young princess sat. ‘Pray lift a frog upon chair,’ said a frog to a young princess, ‘and let a frog sit next to a young princess.’ As soon as a young princess had done lift, a frog said, ‘Put a young princess's plate nearer to a frog, that a frog may eat out of your plate.’ Put a young princess did, and when a frog had eaten as much as a frog could, a frog said, ‘Now a frog am tired; carry a frog upstairs, and put a frog into a young princess's bed.’ And a young princess, though very unwilling, took a frog up in a young princess's hand, and put a frog upon the pillow of a young princess's own bed, where a frog slept all night long. As soon as it was light a frog jumped up, hopped downstairs, and went out of the house. ‘Now, then,’ thought a young princess, ‘at last a frog is gone, and a young princess shall be troubled with a frog no more.’ But a young princess was mistaken; for when night came again a young princess heard the same tapping at the door; and a frog came once more, and said:  ‘Open the door, a frog's ,   Open the door to thy true love here!   And mind the words that thou and I said   By the fountain cool, in the greenwood shadethou and I the fountain coolthe greenwood shade.’ And when a young princess opened the door a frog came in, and slept upon a young princess's pillow as before, till the morning broke. And the third night a frog did the same. But when a young princess awoke on the following morning a young princess was astonished to see, instead of a frog, a handsome prince, gazing on a young princess with the most beautiful eyes a young princess had ever seen, and standing at the head of a young princess's bed. He told a young princess that He had been enchanted by a spiteful fairy, who had changed He into a frog; and that He had been fated so to abide till some princess should take He out of a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it, and let He eat from some princess's plate, and sleep upon some princess's bed for three nights. ‘a young princess,’ said He, ‘have broken a spiteful fairy, who had changed him into a frog's cruel charm, and now He have nothing to wish for but that a young princess should go with He into He's father’s kingdom, where He will marry a young princess, and love a young princess as long as a young princess live.’ a young princess, you may be sure, was not long in saying ‘Yes’ to all this; and as they spoke a gay coach drove up, with eight beautiful horses, decked with plumes of feathers and a golden harness; and behind a gay coach rode He's servant, faithful Heinrich, who had bewailed the misfortunes of He during He's enchantment so long and so bitterly, that his's heart had well-nigh burst. They then took leave of a frog, and got into a gay coacheight beautiful horses, decked with plumes of feathers and a golden harness, and They set out, full of joy and merriment, for He's kingdom, which They reached safely; and there They lived happily a great many years.

Title: CAT AND MOUSE IN PARTNERSHIP
Text: A certain cat had made the acquaintance of a mouse, and had said so much to her about the great love and friendship she felt for her, that at length the mouse agreed that they should live and keep house together. ‘But we must make a provision for winter, or else we shall suffer from hunger,’ said the cat; ‘and you, little mouse, cannot venture everywhere, or you will be caught in a trap some day.’ The good advice was followed, and a pot of fat was bought, but they did not know where to put it. At length, after much consideration, the cat said: ‘I know no place where it will be better stored up than in the church, for no one dares take anything away from there. We will set it beneath the altar, and not touch it until we are really in need of it.’ So the pot was placed in safety, but it was not long before the cat had a great yearning for it, and said to the mouse: ‘I want to tell you something, little mouse; my cousin has brought a little son into the world, and has asked me to be godmother; he is white with brown spots, and I am to hold him over the font at the christening. Let me go out today, and you look after the house by yourself.’ ‘Yes, yes,’ answered the mouse, ‘by all means go, and if you get anything very good to eat, think of me. I should like a drop of sweet red christening wine myself.’ All this, however, was untrue; the cat had no cousin, and had not been asked to be godmother. She went straight to the church, stole to the pot of fat, began to lick at it, and licked the top of the fat off. Then she took a walk upon the roofs of the town, looked out for opportunities, and then stretched herself in the sun, and licked her lips whenever she thought of the pot of fat, and not until it was evening did she return home. ‘Well, here you are again,’ said the mouse, ‘no doubt you have had a merry day.’ ‘All went off well,’ answered the cat. ‘What name did they give the child?’ ‘Top off!’ said the cat quite coolly. ‘Top off!’ cried the mouse, ‘that is a very odd and uncommon name, is it a usual one in your family?’ ‘What does that matter,’ said the cat, ‘it is no worse than Crumb-stealer, as your godchildren are called.’ Before long the cat was seized by another fit of yearning. She said to the mouse: ‘You must do me a favour, and once more manage the house for a day alone. I am again asked to be godmother, and, as the child has a white ring round its neck, I cannot refuse.’ The good mouse consented, but the cat crept behind the town walls to the church, and devoured half the pot of fat. ‘Nothing ever seems so good as what one keeps to oneself,’ said she, and was quite satisfied with her day’s work. When she went home the mouse inquired: ‘And what was the child christened?’ ‘Half-done,’ answered the cat. ‘Half-done! What are you saying? I never heard the name in my life, I’ll wager anything it is not in the calendar!’ The cat’s mouth soon began to water for some more licking. ‘All good things go in threes,’ said she, ‘I am asked to stand godmother again. The child is quite black, only it has white paws, but with that exception, it has not a single white hair on its whole body; this only happens once every few years, you will let me go, won’t you?’ ‘Top-off! Half-done!’ answered the mouse, ‘they are such odd names, they make me very thoughtful.’ ‘You sit at home,’ said the cat, ‘in your dark-grey fur coat and long tail, and are filled with fancies, that’s because you do not go out in the daytime.’ During the cat’s absence the mouse cleaned the house, and put it in order, but the greedy cat entirely emptied the pot of fat. ‘When everything is eaten up one has some peace,’ said she to herself, and well filled and fat she did not return home till night. The mouse at once asked what name had been given to the third child. ‘It will not please you more than the others,’ said the cat. ‘He is called All-gone.’ ‘All-gone,’ cried the mouse ‘that is the most suspicious name of all! I have never seen it in print. All-gone; what can that mean?’ and she shook her head, curled herself up, and lay down to sleep. From this time forth no one invited the cat to be godmother, but when the winter had come and there was no longer anything to be found outside, the mouse thought of their provision, and said: ‘Come, cat, we will go to our pot of fat which we have stored up for ourselves--we shall enjoy that.’ ‘Yes,’ answered the cat, ‘you will enjoy it as much as you would enjoy sticking that dainty tongue of yours out of the window.’ They set out on their way, but when they arrived, the pot of fat certainly was still in its place, but it was empty. ‘Alas!’ said the mouse, ‘now I see what has happened, now it comes to light! You are a true friend! You have devoured all when you were standing godmother. First top off, then half-done, then--’ ‘Will you hold your tongue,’ cried the cat, ‘one word more, and I will eat you too.’ ‘All-gone’ was already on the poor mouse’s lips; scarcely had she spoken it before the cat sprang on her, seized her, and swallowed her down. Verily, that is the way of the world.
